oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Text of Senate Bill 1000, An Act Creating the Rural Electrification Authority of Tennessee for the Purpose of Promoting and Encouraging the Fullest Possible Use of Electric Energy in the State by Making Electric Energy Available to Certain Inhabitants of the State the Lowest Cost Consistent with Sound Economy and Prudent Management; Authorizing the Authority to Sell and Distribute Electric Energy and to Construct or Otherwise Acquire a System or Systems for the Generation, Transmission and Distribution of Electric Energy to Carry Out the Purpose of This Act; Providing for the Rights, Powers and Duties of the Authority; Authorizing and Regulating the Issuance of Bonds by the Authority; and Providing for the Payment of Such Bonds and the Rights of the Holders Thereof.

By the 1930s, nearly 90% of the U. S. population living in urban areas had electricity while only 10% of the rural population did. To address this problem, the Roosevelt Administration created the Rural Electrification Administration [REA] in 1935. By 1939, the efforts of the REA, Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA), etc. had increased the number of rural households with electricity to 25%.
